content: back to the greatest hits this week more
clip-on features for your modular tiles
let's start by making an akai VIN cut two chipboard squares two inches draw a
sort of rough tunnel entrance on it and cut that out leaving about a centimetre
of material at the bottom then cut out a two by one and a half inch rectangle of
double corrugated cardboard and hot glue the two frames to it like this and then
add corrugation cladding you'll notice we've done the same thing as in episodes
32 and 35 we've made a clip a quarter inch wide and a half inch tall that
takes some packing insert foam and break it into small pieces and begin hot
gluing them on leave some of the tunnel exposed at the top and just kind of
shape them into a slope like this and that's it we'll paint it later on
how about a font again two two inch squares of chipboard hot glued on to a
rectangle of double corrugated then measure out a strip of chipboard that's
15 millimeters tall and 80 millimeters long pull it through your fingers to
induce a natural curve to it draw and cut out a two inch diameter circle and
cut it in half hot glue this half to the strip as you see here then hot glue that
assembly to the clip itself make sure that there's hot glue sealing all the
inner edges revisit it if you have to paint same as the first five episodes
make a mat your dungeon for me that's based in black sponge on medium gray and
sponge on light gray use a brush to stipple the places that the sponge can't
quite get too
so the cave-in is done for the font you can paint it however you like if you
want to do read for like a health or blue for mana I'm thinking of Diablo
here but we'll just do water for now so for the font we'll paint the water solid
blue and then with one or two lighter shades of blue I just kind of streak it
in and I mixed a bit of acrylic water same
stuff is from episode 44 and poured it in this right here is why it was
important to make sure that the hot glue was all sealed give it a couple days to
cure and after it's done just hot glue something interesting to the wall how
about a clip on for the tavern tiles we made in episode 10 a window again double
corrugated cardboard rectangle two by one and a half inch measure in by 3/8 of
an inch on three sides and cut out the middle apply corrugation cladding and
take some cross stitching mesh sometimes referred to as granny grating and cut
out a piece at a 45 degree angle like this and hot glue it in place then apply
dark brown prepare some wood planks out of popsicle sticks just as described
back in episode 7 chop them to length and hot glue them on two inches across
the top one in 5/8 of an inch for the two vertical ones and another two inch
one going across the bottom once again we've created a quarter inch wide half
inch tall clip and before we go to the table I'd like
to take a moment to thank all wcv sponsors this week I draw your attention
to hero's horde which is an excellent resource for 3d printed scenery
including but not limited to Altru tiles products so if you're into 3d printing
even if it's just to supplement your conventional crafting it is worth a
click to check it out and see what's what alright so here's the font you'll
see in a minute I glued it on a little bit crooked but other than that it came
out well I'm pretty happy with it and the cave in which I did dust a little
bit with a white dry brush just to make it pop a little bit more and then of
course we have the window for our tavern tiles that we did back in episode 10 so
we'll pop that on and then bring it down here for a closer look
yeah he's a pretty neat I'm happy with how these came out remember that you can
use these to connect two tiles together just another way to secure them on the
table just split the distance across two walls back of the tunnel well you may or
may not need that I guess if there's something beyond it that the players
might go to otherwise you could leave it to blank
I am why lock thank you for joining me and I'll see you next time
you
